title: Incredible moment lightning hits volcanic lava

organizations.name: caters news agency paul harper the sun  this

text:
Photographer Hernando Rivera snapped these incredible images of lightning vs. lava at Mexican volcano February 6, 2017 12:06pm Graphic designer Hernando Rivera camped out in Mexico and snapped these incredible images. Picture: Caters News Agency Paul Harper The Sun 
THIS is the spectacular moment a photographer captured lightning bolts striking lava spurts from an erupting volcano. 
Hernando Rivera struck gold with the dazzling snaps at the Volcán de Colima, The Sun reports. 
The graphic designer camped out in freezing conditions around 12km from the famous site in central Mexico. 
This proved the perfect vantage point of the centuries-old active volcano, which is surrounded by an 8km exclusion zone. 
His stunning pictures, taken last Thursday, show white-hot lava spouting from the crater 3,800m above sea level, before lightning bolts emerge from clouds of black smoke. Damn. Picture: Caters News Agency Source: Caters News Agency Picture: Caters News Agency Source: Caters News Agency 
“When the volcano erupts, it sounds like a big bomb,” Hernando, 34, said. 
“It can be dangerous being so close, but mainly I am excited rather than scared. I was alone at night when I took them. I like to go alone.” 
“Sometimes I get as close as 7km or 5km, but on this occasion I was 12km away. When I took the pictures, my reaction was one of happiness because they look spectacular. 
“The lightning is caused by friction within particles. They are too hot and crash, creating static, and this kind of phenomenon leads to lightning. Stunning. Picture: Caters News Agency Source: Caters News Agency Hernando kept his distance, snapping these images from 12km away. Picture: Caters News Agency Source: Caters News Agency Lava spurts high above the volcano in Mexico. Picture: Caters News Source: Caters News Agency 
“Of course it is hard to capture such an image, because you need to wait many hours and stay watching and ready all the time.” 
Thousands of lightning flashes have been observed over volcanoes, with scientists believing the bolts originate from the material ejected from the volcano and the charge formation processes within the ash clouds. 
Hernando, who lives with his partner Sophey and their two French bulldogs, is originally from Mexico City, but now lives in Colima.
